text_explanation_contain: A boundary indicates a point at which software behaviour changes noticeably in response to small changes in input values. Boundary value analysis focuses on testing these edge cases to identify potential faults. A corresponding explanation should be complete and clear/understandable, i.e., by reporting the two input values and clearly describing their difference, as well as the difference of system behaviour.
text_email_clarity: The given explanations are clear but would be easier to grasp if my comments on completeness were addressed (see below)
text_email_correctness: Simply adding factually accurate explanations. As an example in Q2.1 "Adding a plus and tag after the local part (user+tag)" is not correct, as the tag is within the local part.
text_email_completeness: A complete explanation should clearly explain important aspects, e.g., that in Q2.2 it is referring to RFC-5322, what is the local part, what is punycode.
text_email_usefulness: A visible difference in behaviour: In Q2.1 and Q2.2 I cannot see the difference between two valid classes if the explanation does not show me how they are managed differently by the software.
text_bytecnt_clarity: In Q3.1 explain what it means to have a "visible" count.
text_bytecnt_correctness: All the explanations seem correct, given my assumptions.
text_bytecnt_completeness: In Q3.2, explain what is the threshold, while in Q3.5 explain both errors in the output.
text_bytecnt_usefulness: Q3.3 is not useful since it does not describe a boundary: both outputs belong to the same behavioural class
text_date_clarity: In Q4.1 and Q4.2 explain what is a zero padded year
text_date_correctness: The explanation should match the boundary pair. In 4.2, the explanation mentions " with day and month at 10" but in one of the elements of the pair month is 9.
text_date_completeness: In Q4.3, completely describe the boundary and not just one of the values (1). Q4.4 is complete since it reports both boundary values and clarifies the expected formatting.
text_date_usefulness: In Q4.1, i do not see any different output class in the pair. The explanation mentions that there is a change in "the output's year field from 3 to 4 digits" but I always see 4 digits.
text_bmi_clarity: In Q5.2, the sentence "showing the threshold is weight equals 1 kg." must be improved since 1kg is not always a threshold between classes.
text_bmi_correctness: Q5.5 provides a wrong depiction of the causal relationship between input and output
text_bmi_completeness: In Q5.1 it would be useful to report or provide a link to the standard formula.
text_bmi_usefulness: Q5.5 should better characterize the identified boundary, since it corresponds to a behaviour that is more general, that does not depend on the height value
text_use_reason: Automated test generators that provide explanations help identifying root causes of behaviours (e.g., bugs)
text_one_change: Adding links to external resources in order to balance between completeness and conciseness

text_explanation_contain:
The threshold boundaries where changes in system behavior are expected should be clearly defined, along with the system’s expected response at those points.
For example, in an AI context where model robustness against outliers is critical, the system should maintain stable sensitivity as long as the proportion of outliers remains within an acceptable threshold — no more than 10%. Beyond this threshold, a degradation in model performance may occur, and appropriate system handling or alerts should be expected.

The introductory example in this survey illustrates boundary value analysis well. Many practitioners—including software testers—tend to think of “edge” values only as the absolute limits of an input range, but this example makes it clear that boundary values can occur in other places as well.
text_email_clarity: All examples are clear except the one on internationalization. Testers unfamiliar with the related RFC may find it surprising and could miss it. Including this atypical case in the preamble would help prepare testers.
text_email_correctness: I have no issues with correctness
text_email_completeness: Completeness is a recurring challenge—after five examples, it still feels like other cases could exist. As a tester, I’d wonder how to generalize my test cases to cover those possibilities.
text_email_usefulness: I have no issues with correctness
text_bytecnt_clarity: The introduction did not mention anything about errors so that came as a surprise. If I don't dig deep, I don't get the bounds error format BoundsError("kMGTPE", N) - what does N mean here?
text_bytecnt_correctness: The lack of clarity makes it difficult to judge correctness
text_bytecnt_completeness: I repeat my observation from the previous example - I'm not sure if showing a handful of gotcha cases creates an impression of completeness
text_bytecnt_usefulness: The lack of clarity makes it difficult to judge usefulness

text_explanation_contain: The boundary behavior explanation should indicate the output expected from the unit under test at the boundary value(s) of the input parameter(s).
text_email_correctness: The explanations seem correct (TIL about spaces, internationalization, and punycode encoding in email addresses)
text_email_completeness: The explanations are mostly complete, but it may be useful to mention the impact of the position of dots and spaces in the local part of the email address on its validity.
text_bytecnt_clarity:
Mostly clear explanations, the explanation for BC3 took some re-reads to understand -- the input type is listed as "height cm, weight kg."
BC4 and BC5 raise the same error type but their explanations are worded differently. BC5 does not mention the boundary value (999999999999998341339).
text_bytecnt_completeness: The explanations are mostly complete.  The explanation for BC5 could have indicated the boundary value, as could the specification of the error that is raised in BC4 and BC5 (what does the number in BoundsError signify?).
text_date_clarity:
The explanation for Date1 mentions the change in the year from 3 to 4 digits, but the year has 4 digits in both cases (0199 and 0200).
The explanation for Date2 mentions the month (10) but the month is irrelevant for this boundary value condition (the relevant condition is the change in the year from -1 to 0).
text_date_correctness: For Date1, the boundary being explained is unclear to me. There is no change in the number of digits, as indicated in the explanation.
text_date_completeness:
Mostly complete, except Date1 and Date2, but the formatting of the explanation across the examples is inconsistent (e.g., ranges are sometimes indicated as (x:y) and sometimes in words such as between x and y).
For Date2, the explanation is a bit "too complete" - mentioning the month parameter that does not impact the output.
text_date_usefulness: All useful explanations, except for the case of Date1 that I don't understand. :)
text_use_reason: They might be more consistent with the code.
text_one_change: The indication of boundary values and maybe more consistent format across the explanations

The explanation would be more correct if it described not only the behaviors of the values but also how they differ.
For example, in 3.4, it says that it causes an out-of-bound error but so do the other input value. The explanation is more correct if it focuses on the "9" and "10" differences.
text_bytecnt_completeness: Stating the assumptions such as in 3.2
text_bytecnt_usefulness: I find it hard to see the usefulness of the explanation in Q3.3. For me, if there is no boundary, the explanation is not useful because it is already apparent in the example itself.
text_date_clarity: The explanation would be clearer and more natural if it describes the valid output first then how it switches to invalid. For example, in 4.4, it is more natural to say how it switched from valid to error.
text_date_correctness: In general, the lack of completeness causes issues with correctness. For example, the assumption in 4.5 misses the upperbound for the days which is not completely correct since according to the error, it says "Day: 0 out of range ***(1:31)***" .
text_date_completeness: For functions with multiple parameters, it would be more complete if also describes the values of the other arguments as well. For example, why in 4.4 the year and day are 187 and 9 respectively? Would any other value work for them?
text_date_usefulness: The reasoning behind the different behaviours.
text_bmi_clarity: For me personally, the current format of the explanation e.g., "switching from x to y, results in z" can be improved. It would be clearer if it would be something like "x results in X', then incrementing the value by 1 to y results in Y'
text_bmi_correctness:
Avoiding extra information that can make the interpretation of the example incorrect. For example, in 5.2, the use of the word threshold in "threshold is weight equals 1 kg." is a bit weird and not accurate. especially that there is a weird jump between underweight and obese. shouldn't the "threshold" be between normal and underweight for example?

Side note: it is very hard to evaluate correctness of the explanation without being biased towards the example itself.

When the explanation is addressing a weird value like 0 kg (e.g., 5.2) which is impossible, a clarification would improve the correctness.

text_explanation_contain: It should describe what happens at the critical values of the system being tested.
text_email_completeness: What about negative numbers? Backslashes /? Combinations of special char. Examples of them are missing.

text_date_completeness: The explanation omits that this format change is due to standard ISO 8601 date formatting, which uses a sign for negative years and zero-pads non-negative ones. It also doesn’t mention the consistent use of zero-padding for month/day fields regardless of sign.
text_date_usefulness: The explanation would be more valuable if it clarified why the formatting shift occurs.
